title: Roman Aqueducts and Urban Life
description: A quick, practical guide to Roman Aqueducts and Urban Life.

hook.text: Rome's aqueducts delivered 1 million cubic meters of water dailyâ€”more per person than most modern cities.

buildup.text: Eleven aqueducts fed the city, some stretching 90 kilometers. They used gravity aloneâ€”no pumps at all.

discovery.text: Engineers maintained a precise slope of about 1 meter drop per kilometer to keep water flowing steadily.

twist.text: Most of the system was underground. The famous arched bridges were only needed to cross valleys.

climax.text: Public fountains, baths, and toilets made Rome the cleanest ancient city. Water shaped its entire culture.

punchline.text: Gravity powered the world's first water grid.

quiz.question: How did Roman aqueducts move water across long distances?
options: Gravity and a precisely maintained downhill slope
